content: The Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2002 facilitates compliance with federal paperwork requirements. The Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2002 amends the Paperwork Reduction Act to require the Director of OMB to publish a list of compliance assistance resources for small businesses annually. Additionally, it establishes an agency point of contact for small businesses. The Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2002 amends title 44, United States Code to require each agency to establish a point of contact for small business concerns to assist with information collection and paperwork control. This point of contact must be established within one year of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for further reduction of paperwork for certain small businesses. The Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2002 requires agencies to establish a point of contact for small businesses to assist with information collection. It also includes provisions to reduce paperwork burdens for small businesses with fewer than 25 employees. Establishment of task force on information collection and dissemination under Chapter 35 of title 44, United States Code, to assist small businesses with reducing paperwork burdens. Establishment of a task force to study streamlining requirements for small businesses regarding information collection and dissemination. The Director determines the number of representatives and agencies involved, with the task force chaired by a representative of the Director and including at least 2 representatives from the Department of Labor. The task force studying streamlining requirements for small businesses includes representatives from various agencies such as the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, Department of Transportation, Small Business Administration, Internal Revenue Service, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Agriculture, Department of the Interior, and General Services Administration. The task force studying streamlining requirements for small businesses includes representatives from various agencies, including the General Services Administration and two additional agencies. The task force aims to integrate information collection across Federal agencies and explore consolidating information requirements for small businesses to submit in a unified format. The task force studying streamlining requirements for small businesses aims to integrate information collection across Federal agencies and explore consolidating information requirements for small businesses to submit in a unified format. This includes examining the feasibility and benefits of publishing a list of collections of information applicable to small business concerns, organized by industry sector description for easier compliance identification. The task force aims to examine cost savings and recommend implementing electronic submission systems to the Federal Government. They also plan to improve electronic dissemination of information collected under Federal requirements and develop an interactive Governmentwide system for small businesses to better understand Federal requirements. The task force aims to streamline Federal regulatory requirements for small businesses by considering coordination between Federal and State reporting requirements and providing contacts for information collection requirements from other agencies. The task force will also publish draft reports for public comment and include any additional or dissenting views from task force members. The task force will submit a report of its findings to various committees and the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman within 1 year of the enactment of the Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2002. The task force established by the Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2002 will submit a report of its findings to specific committees and the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman within 2 years of enactment. The task force will terminate upon completion of its work. The term 'small business concern' is defined under section 3 of the Small Business Act. Establishment of task force on information collection and dissemination and authorization of appropriations. Regulatory enforcement reports. Each agency must submit an initial report by December 31, 2003, and a final report by December 31, 2004, to specific committees and the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman. The agency must submit a final report to designated members and officers, detailing enforcement actions and civil penalties assessed against small entities, including reductions or waivers of penalties, for the 1-year periods starting on October 1, 2002, and October 1, 2003. Each report under this subsection shall include definitions of "enforcement actions", "reduction or waiver", and "small entity" as used in the report.
